awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Farmer Organizations and Development Actors in a Pandemic: Responses to COVID-19 and the Food-Water-Energy Nexus
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The COVID-19 pandemic has adversely affected the agricultural sector, resulting in supply chain problems among many other challenges. Such problems are mitigated differently by independent farmers, farming collectives, and development organizations. How responses to the pandemic are organized across these different scales affects successes and failures. The pandemic environment thus offers a critical window into the reasons for success and failure in farming activities as the pandemic continues to evolve. This doctoral dissertation research investigates the responses of agricultural development actors and small-scale farmer organizations to the Covid-19 pandemic in multiple locations. In addition to contributing to training a U.S.-based doctoral student in scientific cultural anthropology, the research findings will be disseminated widely to academic and non-academic audiences. 

This project uses resilience theory to investigate the processes by which farmers at different levels of organization adapt to ongoing crises. The investigators focus on three research questions: 1) How has the pandemic affected the flow of capital and who controls the flow? 2) What are the vulnerabilities in food-energy-water systems exposed by the pandemic? 3) What can answers to these questions reveal about mechanisms to build resiliency? Through ethnographic interviews with development actors operating at different scales and locations, and online participant observation in virtual meeting spaces that have become more prevalent during the time of the pandemic, this study traces the flow of capital, project funding, and ideas between different agricultural development actors as the pandemic continues to unfold. This research contributes to contemporary anthropology by integrating approaches from disaster anthropology, development anthropology, and political ecology to better understand pandemic responses and shifts in development practice with far-reaching implications for local livelihoods on a global scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

PD/PI Name: Rebecca K Zarger, Principal Investigator, Atte Penttila, Co-Principal Investigator, Department of Anthropology, University of South Florida

Overview of Research

The overarching aim of this multi-sited research was to understand responses to the Covid-19 crisis from various levels of agricultural development actors and the roles that the actors have played in co-producing resilient communities, particularly farmer organizations (FOs) through traditional and online ethnographic research at sites across several continents, encompassing 13 organizations.

While the research location in the physical sense was mainly online, completed during the first two years of the Covid-19 pandemic, this dissertation research was global. The agri-agencies in the focus of the study are primarily located in major cities in Europe, while most of the FOs, the local/regional scale portion of the study, operate in rural and semi-rural areas of Africa, Asia, and Latin America. This variability allowed for systematic comparison of pandemic responses across scales within the AgriCord agricultural development network of actors.

This research design allowed for a critical engagement with development cooperation, the concept of resilience, the Food-Energy-Water Nexus, and disaster response and recovery. 

Research questions are as follows:

  1. What were/are the perceived risks and subsequent responses of farmers’ organizations (FOs) (and communities) and networked agricultural development agencies to the Covid-19 crisis in the study sites? How does this vary across study sites?
  2. How might these responses inform global funding/capital flow resiliency with the development organizations?
  3. How might these responses inform community resiliency with the FOs and the communities they are in?
  4. How might these responses inform policies around the Food-Energy-Water Nexus in the development context?

Summary of Research Completed

The project supported the completion of doctoral dissertation research in Anthropology by Co-PI Penttila through a purposeful sample of its member agri-agencies, and farmers’ organizations that are supported by AgriCord. Farmer organizations who participated in the study were located in Nepal, Phillippines, Kenya, Uganda, Palestine, Tanzania, as well as funding agencies and global scale agricultural development actors located in Belgium and Finland.

Data collection included semi-structured interviews carried out virtually with Farmer Organization leaders and members, as well as within donor organizations including the European Union, International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), and Agri-Cord staff and leadership. The research was completed during the height of the Covid-19 Global Pandemic and focused on the impacts of that on small-holder farmer organizations in Global South countries around the globe.

Field-based research in Brussels, Belgium and Helsinki, Finland was carried out with agricultural development actors and organizations. Data collection during the study also included attendance and participation in online webinars as well as tracking media and content analysis of pandemic-related impacts on agricultural development, food-energy-water systems, and related topics. 

Significant results of the project include the following:

  • Responses across agricultural development actors vary significantly across locations, scales, and structure of farmer organizations.
  • The ability to respond with greater resilience appears to be linked to having a past history of disaster response and thus, also preparing for future disasters.
  • Mental health of actors involved in agricultural development emerged as a significant impact of experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic among research participants. This is a less-anticipated finding but is emerging from the data set.
  • Food, energy, and water sectors appear to be impacted in very different ways across field sites and organizations. More will be determined on this as findings are finalized.

Publications and outcomes of the project

Products include a completed doctoral dissertation, conference presentations and a keynote speech in Finland to development agencies, an article, and professional development.

Atte Penttilä 2022. "Farmers’ Organizations and Development Actors in a Pandemic: Responses to Covid-19 and the Food-Energy-Water Nexus". USF Tampa Graduate Theses and Dissertations. https://digitalcommons.usf.edu/etd/9805  

Atte Penttilä 2023. Farmers’ Organizations and Development Actors in a Pandemic: Responses to Covid-19 and the Food-Energy-Water Nexus. Development Days Conference 2023: Conflicts and Development Revisited — Prospects for Peace in Times of Emergency. Helsinki, Finland.

Atte Penttilä 2023. Farmers for sustainable and responsible food systems and forestry – from local action to systemic change. Keynote speech at Food and Forest Development Finland seminar.

Atte Penttilä. 2023. From fertiliser crises to a circular economy of nutrients: what is the role of civil society in catalysing the transition?. Keynote speech at Where is the Global Food System Heading? -seminar in Helsinki, Finland.

Penttilä, Atte. 2021. “Land-Use Change at the Food-Energy-Water Nexus: Political Ecology of the Bladen River Watershed, Belize.” Global Extractivisms and Alternatives Initiative (EXALT) Symposium Extractivisms and Alternatives. Helsinki, Finland.

Penttilä contributing author for: Simola, N, and K Vuori, eds. 2021. Forest and farm producer organizations building resilience. Strength in numbers and landscapes. Global findings from case studies. Forest and Farm Facility. Rome: FAO.
